subsection.title: Rate of Change

assemblage.title: Rate of Change
assemblage.p: A rate of change is a type of ratio that measures how one variable changes with respect to another.

statement.p: In order to fire a particular kind of pottery, the pieces must first be cured by raising the temperature slowly and evenly. Sonia checks the temperature in the drying oven at ten-minute intervals, and records the following data.
The heat in the oven should not increase any faster than 0.5 degree per minute. Is the temperature in the oven within the safe limits?

stack.p: A graph of the data is shown at right.
Sonia calculates the rate at which the temperature is rising by finding the following ratio: \dfrac{\text{change in temperature}}{\text{change in time}}

subsection.p: You can check that over each ten-minute interval the temperature again rises by four degrees, so it appears that the oven is heating up at an acceptable rate.

statement.p: What is a rate of change?

answer.p: A type of ratio that measures how one variable changes with respect to another

subsection.title: Slope
subsection.p: We introduce some new notation to use when calculating a rate of change.

assemblage.p: The Greek letter \blert{\Delta}Delta (\Delta)change inDelta\DeltaDelta ("delta") is used in mathematics to indicate change.

subsection.p: In , we used the variable x to represent time and y to represent the temperature, so we denote the ratio \dfrac{\text{change in temperature}}{\text{change in time}} by \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}. With this notation, we calculate the rate of change of temperature between the data points (20, 78) and (50, 90) as follows: \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\dfrac{\text{12 degrees}}{\text{30 minutes}} = 0.4 \text{ degree per minute}

We can illustrate the rate of change on a graph of the data, as shown below. We move from the point (20, 78) to the point (50, 90) by moving horizontally a distance of \Delta x = 30 and then vertically a distance of \Delta y = 12.

The rate of change of one variable with respect to another is so important in applications that the ratio \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} is given a name; it is called slope, and is usually denoted by the letter mm as slope.

subsection.title: Meaning of Slope

assemblage.p: The slope of a line measures the rate of change of y with respect to x.

subsection.p: In different situations, this rate might be interpreted as a rate of growth or a speed. The slope of a graph can give us valuable information about the variables involved.

li.p: Choose any two points on the line, say G(2,100) and H(4,200) shown in the figure. As we move from G to H we find m = \dfrac{\Delta D}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{100}{2} = 50 The slope of the line is 50.

warning.p: In , we refer to a point by a capital letter and the coordinates of the point, like this: H(4,200). This means that t=4 and D=200 at the point H. Do not confuse the coordinates of a particular point with the values of \Delta t and \Delta D obtained by moving from one point to a second point.

statement.p: What does the slope of a line measure?

answer.p: the rate of change of y with respect to x

subsection.title: Geometrical Meaning of Slope
subsection.p: Suppose we graph two lines with positive slope on the same coordinate system. If we move along the lines from left to right, then the line with the larger slope will be steeper. This makes sense if we think of the slope as a rate of change: The line whose y-coordinate is increasing faster with respect to x is the steeper line.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: You can verify the slope given for each line in figure (a) by computing \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}. For each unit you increase in the x-direction, the steepest line increases 2 units in the y-direction, the middle line increases 1 unit in the x-direction, and the flattest line increases only \dfrac{1}{3} unit.

Figure (b) shows several lines with negative slopes. These lines slant downwards or decrease as we move from left to right. The more negative the slope, the more sharply the line decreases. For both increasing and decreasing graphs, the larger the absolute value of the slope, the steeper the graph.

warning.p: Slopes measure the relative steepness of two lines only if they are graphed on axes with the same scales. Changing the scale on either the x-axis or the y-axis can greatly alter the appearance of a graph.

statement.p: What sort of lines have negative slopes?

answer.p: Lines that slant downwards or decrease as we move from left to right
